description: Middle English, from a Germanic base akin to German Scheibe, late Old Norse skífa (“slice”), all ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *skey- (“to split”). For more see shive.

entries.meaning: A wheel having a groove in the rim for a rope to work in, and set in a block, mast, or similar; the wheel of a pulley.
A sliding scutcheon for covering a keyhole.

verbs.description: sheave (third-person singular simple present sheaves, present participle sheaving, simple past and past participle sheaved)

entries.meaning: To gather and bind into a sheaf.
examples: From him did forty million serfs (...) receive
Rich freeborn lifelong land, whereon to sheave
